section.hand:
Copie of a letter to my L. T
re
r De
c
ult
o
1591.

page.lettertext:
fol.319r
1591 31 Decem
b
To my L Trea
s
Belgia 1591. De
c
May it please yo
r
good L. there is an other Messenger come hither
from D. Cassimir, w
th
divers letters of credence, to
e General
states, to the Count, to Mons
r
Busenval, and to my self
and others. The copie of
at to me I have sent hereinclosed,
and of that w
ch
he was willed to signifie uppon it,
e effect
is this. That
e D. had bin earnestly urged by the Empe-
ro
r
, and by the Archbishop of Ments in speciall, to use
his credit in these Provinces, for persuading the states
to accept of a Treatye. That though he had often refused
to intermeddle therin, yet at last he was wonne upon
the faire presentac
o
ns and promises made unto him, of
all good conditions and faithfull perfourmance, to write
that letter to the General states, wherof heertofore
I have sent yo
r
L.
e transcript. But
e letter being
brought when the Deputies were departed there was
yet no answear made unto it. Nevertheles wheras
his letter was written the last of Oct
o
he writte
unto the Emperor the 24 of No
v
as if the states had
made an answear, and had acquainted him w
th
certaine
causes, for w
ch
they coulde not w
th
their safetie yelde
to any Treaty: supposing by that meanes to drawe some
further matter from the Emperor, upon his answear to
his objections. His letter was written in Dutche
but translated into Frenche and exhibited unto me,
wherof heerinclosed I have sent the copie. The rest
of this Deputies speeches tended to assure me, that
e
Dukes affection was sincere, and wholy bent to advance
the cause of these Contreis, intending also to doe nothing
w
t
out her Ma
ties
good liking. Howbeit for himself he
was persuaded, although it might carry much matter of
daungerous consequence, to come to a Treaty w
t
the Enemie,
yet to graunt a first accesse to the Emperors Ambassado
rs
and to take their Proposition: not w
t
in the Provinces
but upon the Frontiers, yet could not prove prejudiciall
to the state of the Contrey. In w
ch
respect he was
fol.319v
Belgia: 1591 De
c
desirous, to knowe her Ma
ties
inclincation in these causes, to underst
a
my advise of his proceedinges and to keepe correspondence w
t
me by letters, desiring some cipher, for
e better securitie of
writing too and fro. Not to troble yo
r
L. w
t
any [.]
repetition, I tolde him in my answear,
at I woulde certifie
her Ma
tie
of this carefull dealing of the Duke his master:
that I coulde not signifie unto him w
at
her Hig
nes
did resolve
for
at I did not understand, that ether the Emperor or the stat[es]
had written unto her about it: but of this I was assured,
at
if an unfained peace were proposed, w
t
good conditions of assu
rance, her Ma
tie
would embrace it. But unles the motion
were generall, and
at the K. of Spaine might be wrought
to w
t
drawe his forces out of France, it was wholy in vaine
to talke of any treaty. I coulde not satisfie his desire
by any advise from my self for
at a servant and subject of
my qualitie might easily passe his boundes, in so weightie
a cause, w
t
out very good warrant and instruction from home
Nevertheles upon further notice of her Hig
nes
pleasure
I did hope to give him some better contentment. At
o
r
first meeting there was littell other saide: but yet it
seemed by his talke
at he referred somw
at
to his next
comminge to me. It may please yo
r
good L. to pre
scribe me in your next, w
at
libertie I may use in writing
to the Duke, and w
at
report I shall make of her Ma
ties
disposition to hearken to a Treaty. There is a
letter brought hither by a Trompet from Mons
r
de Bylan
one of the Empero
rs
Ambassadors, addressed to the Gener
al
states, Councel of state, and to Count Maurice: requiring
a Passeport for himself alone to come hither, and to pro-
pose suche matter unto them as doth concerne their specia
l
good, and is highly by the Emperor commended unto them
wishing them to take a course that may not seeme too
contemptuous towards the person of the Empero
r
.
[It is]
presumed that his errand would be, to prepare
[.]
fol.320r
Belgia: 1591 De
c
by persuasion, for the rest of the Ambassado
rs
to come hither
The saide partie himself professeth the reformed religion
and being Baron of Reide, and of divers other places in
Juliers and Cleve, mainteneth the same religion among
his subjects, being also, as is supposed, well affected to
theis contreis. But heere is nothing yet resolved for
e answearing of his letter. At
e earnest suite of
e F
r
Kinge and upon demonstration of his present
necessitie to be relieved w
t
further forces, it is accor-
ded by the states of Holland, that they will send him
out of hand between two and 3000 footmen, all of their
owne repartition, excepting some 4 companies, w
ch
are
appointed out of Zeland. And these they thinke
they may imploy out of these Contreis, being troupes
of their owne interteinment, w
t
out demanding or attending
the consent of the other Provinces. If their resolution
hold as I thinke it will, they wilbe ready to be imbarked
w
t
the first winde, w
ch
is westerly at this present.
They have deputed Count Philippe of Nassau to
command in chief: and the next unto him is Coronell
Bulford w
t
e regiment of Scottes.
And thus no other
matter being offered, I take my humble leave De
c
Ult
o
1591.
